text: Can. Brown pour with a beige head. Sweet oatmeal raisin cookie aroma, lots of raisin and cinnamon, kind of creamy. Taste is a little less sweet and less pronounced, but really nice.

5.5%ABV. Brown ale.

Tapped out dark brown. 26 SRM.

Nose is roasted nutty with roasted chestnuts.

Mouthfeel is drip coffee. Palate has caramel, light toffee, roasted chestnuts and a strong base of wheat toast. Element of ume fruitiness, like the wet plum preserves, maybe prunes. Coffee flavor.
Can. Nose brown biscuity malts. Light raisons with cinnamon. Quite malty. Taste raisins and cinnamon. Quite hoppy. Nice raisins notes. Toasted Raisins bread. Interesting.

12 oz can from Cigar City in the hotel room. Pours a clear mahogany brown color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma has mainly cinnamon and raisins, simple but nice. The flavor has raisins, cinnamon, oatmeal sweetness, I can get the nice oatmeal cookie malts, hints of the vanilla, definitely a positive spin on the basic brown ale.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a very dark brown with medium beige head that lasts. The aroma is cocoa, roast, raisin, wood. Medium body, nuts, cocoa, raisin, caramel, nice sweetness, very good.
On tap at CCB tasting room. Pours a nice, dark copper. Smells of vanilla and cinnamon. Taste is very smooth, vanilla and cinnamon in a rich dark beer. This has always been one of my favorites.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2017 Pours a deep brown on tap with fluffy tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of sweet fruit and cookie notes, dead on for the name. Taste follows, oatmeal raisin cookies for sure, a hint of spice, but mostly sweet. Well done.

Muddy chocolate brown body with off white head. Deep fudge aroma with notes of dried fruit and caramel. Sweet but not cloying. Caramel malt chocolate notes and hints of dried fruit. Well made and well rounded. This beer sounds like a gimmick but its not. Classic cigar city.

Tasted on draft at Hunahpu Day. Honestly tasted and smells like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Sometimes not a fan of the gimmicky flavors but this is awesome. Definitely one of my favorite Browns if not the favorite I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a medium to dark brown with a khaki colored head. Gingerbread, faint, cinnamon, and Bakers chocolate on the nose. Full mouthfeel getting moderately astringent toward the finish. Cinnamon macaroon flavor up front. Raisin oatmeal cookie comes through toward the finish. More chocolate gets expressed at the finish and after.
A nice cookie spice of cinnamon and baked sugars waft from the clear brown body. Not much head but doesnt need one. Raisins are definitely apparent in flavor and finish. Yummy.

The name says it all. Dessert beers designed to taste like one particular dessert are almost always set up to fail. Cigar City has crafted one of the exceptions. Holy hell. I dont even like oatmeal raisin cookies all that much and I could drink this stuff by the gallon. Im convinced everything Cigar City touches turns out delicious.

Draft/Fest.

A- Cookies, raisins, cinnamon, vanilla.

A- Brown color, dark liquid, off white head.

T- Oatmeal raisin cookies, spices.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- This was nothing but oatmeal raisin cookies in liquid form and that is a great thing. And the fact that its a brown ale and not an imperial stout makes me appreciate it that much more. So good.

On tap. Almost black pour with a frothy white head. Taste and flavor are exactly what it says - oatmeal raisin cookie. There really arent any other notes. This is what I refer to as a "Jelly Belly" beer, where they just perfectly recreate a flavor. Worth a try even if only for that novelty aspect, but its damn good on its own merits as well.

Dark brown, medium head with a slight caramel colour. Smells a lot like an oatmeal raisin cookie, but with a fair bit of cinnamon. Sweet, cookieish, with a lot of raisin and cinnamon and a fairly oaty character, good.

Draft at CCB. How the hell can a brown ale smell and taste this good??? The aroma and flavor shows all of the elements, raisins, brown sugar, oatmeal and light traces of vanilla. The finish has a warm cookie flavor that is really unbelievable they got the proper flavors here. Impressive brew!
Rated from notes taken 1 Oct 2011 -- From tap in Jax, FL. Last bit from the keg. Had a slight cidery flavor, but mostly one of those "how did they get that flavor in there" beer.
Draft. Pours a fairly clear brown. Minimal white head. Aroma is gritty, grainy and sweet. Taste is initially sweet with a wonderful, straight up oatmeal cookie. Wow. Lots of passion.
Draft - Oatmeal raisin cookie, believe it or not. Jet black with a small beige head. Tastes just as it smell with hints of nut and vanilla. Brilliant.

Awesome aroma of rasins and cinnemon...lots of cinnemon! Really solid though, great flavor of vanilla and oatmeal and super spiced. Nice that it isnt a stout since for all the flavor, it isnt too heavy.

Draft at TAP Global Beer Collection in Delray. Pours an amber brown with a tan head and aroma of oatmeal, roasted malt, and raisin. Taste is delicious, sweet and really does taste like a raisin cookie. Lots of oatmeal, raisin, vanilla, cinnamon, and cookie notes, into the sweet finish. Delicious, unique brew

Im not big on bakery flavor based beers overall. This beer blows this preconception for me out of the water. Love the sweet, aromatic thick headed beer that does in fact taste like an oatmeal raisin cookie. They did not overdo the flavor; thank goodness. This is one of those beers that is tasty to the beer connoisseur and the not that much into beer significant other you might have dragged out with you.
Tap at ccb, tampa. Hazy dark brown color, tanned head. Aroma is sweet notes, malts, some fruits. Nice taste of sweet malts, biscuits, cinnamon, fruity notes.
On tap at brewery. Pours brown with minimal head. Smells like oatmeal and raisins, who would have thought. Taste is the same, the oatmeal cookie. Actually quite drinkable.

Aroma: Oatmeal, Molasses, Sweet Bread

Appearance: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Little Light, Off White Head Ring, Some Lacing

Taste: Oatmeal, Raisins, Mild Brown Sugar

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet

Medium foggy cola brown. Tangy, lightly seet, slikghtly roasty aroma with some cinnamon. Smells like cookies, as advertised. Medium cola body, tangy, light cinnamon, medium sweet but not exactly desserty. Interesting, gets a little clingy - good but ones enough. On tap, World Market.

Tallahassee, Fl - Whole Foods Market - on tap. Dark brown, tea-like pour with a medium thick off-white head. Aroma has some cinnamon accents, a touch of chocolate. Flavor is just like the name of the beer. Definitely pick up all of the elements of a warm oatmeal raisin cookie with a heavy dose of cinnamon in the back end with a splash of vanilla. Mouthfeel does not quite match up with the flavor - could be a tad thicker. Nice way to greet the new Whole Foods in town.
Has a cinnamon aroma and a nice note of cinnamon on what is already a tasty malt backbone.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2013 Tap at CCB. What a great smell. It just what you would find in a oatmeal cookie. Oatmeal, cinnamon, vanilla, brown sugar. Pour dark brown with a off white head. Taste vanilla, cinnamon, oat, and alittle malt. Gray beer. Fun for a brown ale. Enjoy.
I have turned on people that do not like beer and liked this its that good
Growler from ba tasting. Pours mahogany amber small head. Aste and smeels exactly like oakmeal cookies. Great.
Brown, small tan head. Nose is grains, dark fruits, earth. Taste is oatmeal raisin cookie. Very thin watery mouthfeel.

Forgot to rate this.  Pour number 50,000 or something at Hunahpu Day 2013.  Poured a dark brown with a small head.  Aroma of cinnamon, nuts, and, you guessed it, oatmeal.  Flavor is heavy on the cinnamon oatmeal flavor, with a hint of raisins in the background.  Pretty easy drinking, with a medium mouthfeel (maybe even light for the style).  Medium carbonation.  Cool beer.

Rating from 2010. Appears quite dark reddish/brown with a tan head. Smell is huge cinnamon oatmeal raisin cookie - as one would expect! Tastes is similar to the nose but more subtle. Sweet malt and brown sugar. Active carbonation and a bit watery. Overall sweet and spicy, it works in small quantities, I suppose.

Mild aroma but tempting appearance and balanced taste with a sweet mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared by drivendrink a while ago. Thanks Devin! Review from notes.

I could never forget this one. The beer is brown with minimal head. Both the aroma and flavor are oatmeal cookies all the way. Cinnamon, brown sugar, cookie dough, sweet malt. Delectable and delicious. Shockingly reminiscent of a real, genuine oatmeal raisin cookie - the name doesnt lie. A bit of a one trick pony, however. This becomes cloying quickly. A small sample is perfect.

On tap at BX Beer Depots CCB Tap Takeover

Light and delicate flavor profile. Slight sweetness along with artificial raisin and oatmeal. Malt lends a cookie-like flavor as well. Low carbonation and a light velvety mouthfeel. Great novelty, just wish it had a little more body to it.

Tap at the brewery. Cloudy dishwater brown color, no head. Faint cinnamon raisin aroma. Taste starts off like a brown ale and definitely finishes like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Medium full mouthfeel. Glad I got to try this. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown with no head. Aroma of cinnamon, sweet cookie batter and awesomeness. Taste follows only more intense. Such a solid beer. I wish they could bottle this again!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Barcade with James and Streets for CCB event 09/11/2012. Brown-red pour, no lacing, minimal head. Smells and tastes exactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Bread, raisin/dried fruit, spice in the aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, med to high carb. Awesome take.

12/26/10 12 oz bottle in a DT snifter. Nice shade of brown with a slight haze cappuchino head. sweet raisin with hints of cinnamon, vanilla, and nutmeg. Nose leads towards flavor. A little thin though. I wish they used the bolita for this instead of the maduro. Still another great and unique offering from CCB

I havent seen this one in several months. whenever I find it I send it out as extras in all my trades. A great beer that really tastes like the cookie. vanilla, brown sugar, rich and oily oats, it is all in there.
Dark brown medium head.  Light oatmeal smell.slightly sweet oatmeal raisin flavor.  Slightly hoppy sweet finish.  Good, unique.

On tap at Rattle N Hum, I have been waiting to try this beer for a good year now. Purple Brownish pour that leaves an awesome off white thick head. Aromas of oat, caramel, cinnamon, raisin, chocolate. Taste is on par with the aroma with dominant flavors of cinnamon, oatmeal, milk chocolate, vanilla , and traditional brown ale flavors. Mouthfeel is very soft and refreshing. Medium Carbonation that works incredibly well with this brew. Amazingly unique brown ale from one of my favorite brewers.
this is one of those times where the product advertised is pretty much exactly as described. it tastes and smells like a oatmeal cookie. very impressive.

Bottle from James - thanks!  Pours a dark, slightly rusty brown with a large tan head that laces down the sides of the glass.  Aroma is dry roasted malt, light vanilla (maybe some lactose), cinnamon, and light tobacco.  Taste is cinnamon, dry roast, perhaps a touch of fruity sweetness (the raisin?), vanilla, and a very soft touch of some sweeter malt that seems to fade away just as it appears.  Mouthfeel is dry, precise, and light.  I am a huge fan of what cigar city has produced under a beer style that is often times quite bland.  Great beer.

Wow ! Poured from tap a dark rich mahogany color. Aroma is cinnamon, and fruity. Taste is fruity, but a tad too sweet, but what an interesting take on an extreme beer. Once again leave nothing to the imagination of CCB...as usual Bravo CCB....a true premier brewer here in our very own state !!!

Notes from a tasting in April 2011.
Aroma:oats, grain, vanilla, raisins
Taste: spicy, oats, fruity, cinnamon
Overall: This tastes like an oatmeal cookie. A fun beer to drink.

Pours a clear brown with a small bubbly white head. Nose is brown sugar, sweet oats, cinnamon. Flavor is oatmeal, vanilla, brown sugar and spices. Medium bodied and a very delicious and easy drinking beer.

This one impressed me.  Ive had both growler and tap, this one is for tap as part of my catch up notes at CC.  Darker Brown hue, looks great and as I remembered from the past having it in the growler I knew the raisin would come through.  Sure enough it was liquified oatmeal raisin cookie, so much more of a warm in your face nose too.  The palate was great, some sweetness up front, with a chewy cookie feeling with brown sugar notes.  Really fun stuff if you can seek it out.

Appearance: deep mahogany and polished wood which shines clear when held up to the light. Khaki head leaves a thin but solid film.

Nose: cinnamon sprinkles. Fresh baked oatmeal raisin cookies. Brown sugar chunks. Nutmeg sugar granules. Chocolate truffle powder.

Palate: just like biting into a fresh oatmeal raisin cookie with cinnamon sprinkles, only difference is the cookie is cool, not warm. Chocolate truffle powder in the finish. Faint plum essence weaves in and out with plump raisins. Iced coffee with cinnamon sugar oatmeal raisin infusion.

Final Thoughts: delicious. I have found this beer to be an intriguing tasting experiment; much like pumpkin beers, people either love the intrigue of a beer that tastes exactly like a liquid cookie, and others would rather have their cookie and beer separate.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 reddish black. minimal head. aroma of sweet oatmeal, raisin, cookie dough.. some earth as well. flavor of cookie, oatmeal, cinnamon, raisin, and some nutmeg. exactly as advertised.
My favorite brown ale.  Smells like a cookie, tastes like a cookie, what more could you ask for.

I might be a mark for CCB, but Ive had this beer in bottle, and on tap at the brewery and at some bars accross Tampa, this is my secrect indulgence beer.  Pours a light brown color with a little hint of hops as the aroma with some brown sugar, and raisins.  Taste is oatmeal, raisins, brown sugar, and some malt.  I have no idea how they did this, but this beer is mighty tasty, and a great beer.  I wish they still bottled this but also understand why they stopped bottling it as well.

32 ounce growler

A little trade resulted in receiving a 32 ounce growler of this wonderful release. I really was not sure what to expect but given Cigar Citys track record it couldnt be that bad. After all even when they release experiments they seem to be relatively close to style.

Aroma and appearance - The light brown body poured nearly transparently. This made me wonder if the growler was past its prime. The clean hops, oatmeal, and raisins made it evident this was not the case. Completing the breakfast feel was straight black coffee.

Flavor and palate - Malt and black coffee leave an impression of bitterness on the tongue. Soon chased away by raisins, oatmeal, and a scoop of sugar the finish turns into a sweet dessert experience. Carbonation adds depth and reaffirms this was still as fresh as when it was originally filled. I cant wait for the next time I get to try one of their beers.

4oz pour @ Cigar City Sample 8of12.Pours a nice amber color with a tan head. Aroma is cinnamon, oatmeal, biscuit, and raisin. It smells exactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Flavor is oatmeal, raisin, cinnamon and a bitter spicy finish.

Aroma of chocolate and raisins.  Pours dark with little to no head.  Tastes sweet like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  It finishes a little bitter of dark roast hops.  Thinner feeling than it looks.  Very clean finish.  Overall a tasty brew.

Sample from growler. The flavors do come together in a surprising nod to an oatmeal raisin cookie. I think the sweetness and raisin are a little high for me to really get into a long session with this beer. Brown sugar and molasses work throughout as well. The pour is a somewhat muddy brown with a ruby tint to it. Ambitious beer that falls a little short for me.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2012 Cant thank OmegaX enough for this one. The pinnacle of brown ales. Poured a rich brown, with the color of maple syrup. Smelled rich of raisins, vanilla, chocolate and brown sugar. Altogether smelled like raisinettes poured into a vanilla cappuccino. The taste was heavy of hops and RAISINS!! Hints of caramel  and rich milk chocolate provided the most appealing backbone for a beer. The finish was spicy like cinnamon, and had a rather bitter finish. Id have to say that the smell alone was intoxicating, and easily the best beer I have ever smelled in my entire life.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 Insane. I didnt think they could pull this one off so well. The aromas I got from this beer were full of molasses, brown sugar, cinnamon, chocolate, lots of raisin, and a solid malty sweetness. Intoxicating through the scent alone. The body was nice and dark with a light brown head and some thin lacing. The flavor was hypnotic and pleasing with loads of brown sugar, molasses, raisin, and chocolate flavor. Best brown ale Ive ever had and close to one of the best beers Ive ever had - period! Great stuff and cant wait to get more.

Sample at Dunedin. The beer is a dark reddish-brown color with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of sweet spices and dark fruit. Kind of like an oatmeal raisin cookie actually. Medium body with flavors of raisins, sweet caramel malt and cinnamon. The finish is sweet bready malt and cinnamon, again reminiscent of the namesake. Well-executed beer overall.

32oz growler courtesy of smith4498. thanks, jason! pours a hazy, cola-brown with a thin, bubbly, light beige head leaving razor thin rings of lace. aroma is great with smooth, rich cookie batter, cinnamon, and light brown sugar backed by dry oats, subtle hops, and hints of vanilla. flavor is wonderful, really cant believe how much this tastes like a fresh baked cookie, with notes of brown sugar, sweet raisins, cinnamon, and raw oatmeal backed by toasted malt and a touch of hops. palate is medium bodied and very smooth with great carbonation and avoids being overly sweet. overall, a great brown ale.

Re-entering older ratings. Base reste la Maduro qui a déjà été détaillée dans mon autre revue pour cette dernière.
Encore un traitement de la Maduro qui fait plaisir à boire. Mélange de la brune avec un aspect cookie et raisin comme on en trouve aux US. Facile à boire, on ressent en bouche comme au nez, une note de pâte de cookie/pain dépice, bready avec cet aspect fruité du raisin. Une bière qui reste facile à boire, et se prête bien à une dégustation avec un dessert ou fromage. Cest une de ces versions qui améliorent la version originale.

Crushed at GABF 10.  The name is fitting.  Pretty impressive how the flavors actually taste like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Im not usually a fan of cookies, but a cookie-flavored beer is fine with me.

Had on tap at the Cigar City tasting room. Pour was a nice clear dark brown. Aroma was through the roof. No. Really. Smelled like a fresh baked Ginger Snap. Flavor was sweet, toasted oats, vanilla, ginger and brown sugar. Easy to smell, easier to drink. A very nice dessert in a glass!

Brownish clear pour nice reddish color to it great looking beer with a beige creamy head light sticky lacing .... aroma of roasted malts, toffee and light raisin ... taste is malty roasted and silky with raisins, toffee and cinnamon spiced with a bitterness on the tongue that lasts through the finish with a dry and malty finish as well .... an above average brew nice flavors
Seriously?  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Aroma was oatmeal raisin, cinammon and roastyness.  Taste was sweet with a slick mouthfeel.  I could have this for dessert.

On tap at Capones. Poured a deeper reddish/amber color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, raisins, roast, and oatmeal. Tastes of the same with chocolate, some toastiness, and lots of raisins.

Draft at SAVOR. Well, I was certainly unsure about this beer before trying it. Raisins often bring to mind a hot, alcoholic beer that is heavy on the dried fruits. Not refreshing, and overrated. This beer was none of that. The beer poured a brown color with a small, off-white head. Aroma was, as far as I can tell, just like a oatmeal raisin cookie. Ill be darned. The flavor was like they had distilled the essence of an oatmeal raisin cookie and turned it into a beer. Probably a bit gimmicky for some people, but this hit the spot and my heart in a night full of fantastic brews.

Dark brown with a medium head. Smells of raisin, caramel, malt and vanilla. A nice beer taste upfront with light hops that glides into a sweet vanilla at the end. It is like drinking two different drinks. This is a very enjoyable beer.

Pours dark reddish brown with white head, aroma is infected with notes of sour cardboard, with slight oatmeal, dark fruit.  Taste is infected, with notes of oatmeal and raisin, but that sour cardboard is really unappetizing.  I wish it was better, but the infected notes of this ruined it.

Thanks to Kevin for the bottle!  Poured slightly hazy garnety-brown with a gigantic cap of khaki head.  The aroma hinted at infection, with sour metallic and herbal notes above all else.. sweeter raisins and oatmeal were deeper, but you really had to work to find them.  The flavor found more of what I was looking for, with oatmeal, raisins, and caramelized sugars at the core.. the off-notes from the aroma showed up again, and I think this was infected.. finished with tangy, metallic fruity notes and a little brown sugar.  Medium-bodied with way too much carbonation on the palate.. this was unfortunately off, and Id love to try a clean, fresh sample (this was a recent bottle).

12oz bottle from hamilton23. Pours a dark reddish brown color with beige head. The aroma is definitely oatmeal and raisins (go figure) along with some chocolate and spice. I really cant believe it but the taste really is that of an oatmeal raisin cookie. This beer was surprisingly good. I figured that they would make it overly sweet and dessert like to give it those "cookie" like characteristics but god damn this is about as close to biting into an oatmeal raisin cookie as I can imagine. I wouldnt drink it all the time but I would definitely recommend it.

Bottle shared by a friend. I missed this one at GABF 2010 because I was too busy drinking Final Push. I regret nothing, but Im glad I got a second chance on this one. Clear red/copper pour with a big tan head. Malty nose with a bit of tartness and dark fruit. Flavor is cinnamon and raisin with a confectionary baked goods (like a cookie, see) finish. Ridiculous how much this tastes like the name. Different beer and very nicely done.
Pours dark brown with a minimal head.  Has great notes of malt sweetness that show the raisin and sugar, with some nice drying hints of the oatmeal.  Excellent beer.

growler fill at deciccos poured a dark brown in color with some ruby highlights and a thin covering of tan head. aroma has brown sugar, cinnamon, some raisin sweetness, and a slight bit of oats. mouth feel is medium and there is some carbonation that is always appreciated in a growler fill. flavor brings on more cookie flavors, molasses covered oats, cinnamon, brown sugar, vanilla, a bit of raisin, and the brown malt base. an interesting beer for sure and it to grow on me and develop more cookie flavors as it went along.

Bottle shared with Damico.  Thanks again for yet another great Cigar City treat.  Pours a dark brown color with a soapy off white foam head.  Has an aroma of oatmeal raisin.  Sweet caramel taste with spice.  Tastes like you are drinking an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Just amazing.
Sampled at Brewvival 2011.  Clear rust colored pour with tan head.  Sweet raisin, plum, cookie dough, and cinnamen.  Pretty damn apt description.  Really tasty stuff.
on draft.  poured a nice dark brown.  great oatmeal and cinnamon aromas.  Very nice beer that tastes like a liquid cookie.  Nice oatmeal flavor.
Pours a dark brown with a medium head.  Nose has a very faint similarity to brown sugar.  Taste is really below average.  I was dissapointed in this one.

12 oz bottle courtesy of soonah. Thanks John. Pours a dark brown color with a small beige head that soon recedes to a fine film. The aroma is strong with oatmeal, cinnamon and red wine. The flavor does in fact elicit the memory of oatmeal raisin cookies, but with some additional sourness thrown-in. The palate is medium and and carbonation is lively. Finishes long and slightly sour. Overall: The sourness that I pick up here seems a bit out of place, perhaps this one has a slight infection starting.

The top is popped and I pour the brew into my Cigar City snifter.  It lays in the glass a dark brown color with a sandy tan head.  It looks a lot like a cola in the glass.

The smell is bursting with cinnamon and oats.  This really reminds me of the draft version so far.

The moment the first sip hits my tongue I know what it is.  Lots of mixing of raisins, cinnamon, oats and a little bit of vanilla.

Bottle thanks to Tooch4321. One of my earliest Cigar City wants list beers. Brown pour with a sheer massive (too massive tan head of bubbles). Aroma from far away of raisins. Further up there are raisins, cola, nuts (brazil, kola), oatmeal, metal and chocolate. A bit of baked bread. Earthy, a bit dirty. Flavors are metallic, raisins, vanilla, earth and nuts. Husky, tobacco. Super nutty. Sadly I am not seeing the big cookie flavors that the beer promises. Not even a little bit. More like a vinous brown ale, with a touch of cinnamon. A bit too attenuated/dry to capture the essence of any cookie.  Not a bad beer by any means, but I guess I had my hopes up a bit too much. Some oatmeal and raisins in the after taste. Lively bubbles, dry and kind of thin. Still metallic on the finish.  To be honest, it seems like it could be the start of an infection (possibly). Good concept though...

Dark brown with a creamy white head. Aroma of vanilla, oats, dark fruits, and cinnamon. 

Imagine yourself with a brown ale and an oatmeal raisin cookie, now take that cookie and dunk it in the beer. Now let it soak for a second and then eat it. Now that is what this beer tastes like. I really enjoyed drinking it over A 90 min span as a night cap.
Tap at RNH. Pours a deep brown color with nice head. Smells of oats, cinnamon and vanilla. Taste is the same with somre chocolate milk. Very easy drinking and desserty. Very good

Poured from a 12oz bottle from Justin.  Pours dark brown with loads of light tan head.  Smell is interesting, some cinnamon, some vanilla, maltiness.  Taste followed the nose, but had a tartness that was unexpected.

This poured a murky brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of light brown sugar, some toasted malt, caramel, and cinnamon. Flavor was light cinnamon, riasins, and some doughy cookie flavors on top of the the base brown malt. Decent, but not sure I would have picked all the coockie flavors out if I didnt know the name of the beer.
Very good for a seasonal flavored brew.  Oatmeal swetness, brown sugar, and raisins are evident throughout.

Bottle courtesy of Kiefdog, thanks to a great trader.  Ive been waiting to get my hands on this beer for quite sometime, and I definitely was not let down.  A perfect blend of raisins, vanilla, brown sugar and other spices.  A fantastic beer.  Well done!

highly carbonated pour. dark burgundy brown body with a sand colored head. yeast emits a dry egg shell and milk powder scent, burying the malt. only able to notice a light pancake syrup note. underneath active carbonation and harsh bitterness we have toasted barley, oats, flour, black cherries and raisin, cinnamon, pumpkin spice. but with strong bitterness when a beer like this should be chewy, smooth and malt-focused. finish is twangy metallic malt and long buzzing bitterness.

Bottle with many thanks to hopscotch. Pours black with reddish tint. Nose of cookies, cinnamon, vanilla bean, raisin, flour and sugar. Taste of cookie, cinnamon, vanilla bean, caramel malt, raisin and nuts. Well balanced.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark brown color with seemingly a bit of haze; solid, fine-bubbled light-tan head with good retention and great lacing. Brown sugars, lightly spicy cinnamon, a hint of milkiness, and definitely a close approximation of chewy, oatmeal raisin cookies - not quite as much as in the mouth (wait for it), but still a beautifully orchestrated aroma; totally dig this (nothing cloying, nothing stupid). Medium body; medium carbonation. Such a perfect presentation here: creamy, just sweet enough, very mild acidity, with a milky subtexture (new word); cinnamon, brown sugar, and a moderate malty toastiness, along with some undertones of darker fruits and, again, light milkiness; mild roasted maltiness present as well; very nicely approximates an oatmeal raisin cookie served with a glass of milk (Cookie Crunch came to mind as well... but this doesnt have a cloying sugariness); just a neat, tasty, beautifully packaged beer. Yum. Medium finish of some toastiness and very light roast, hints of chocolate; balanced ending.

12 oz bottle shared at a tasting. The first sip tasted almost exactly like yesterdays breakfast: oat-heavy granola with raisins, greek yogurt and a heavy dusting of cinnamon. Mouthfeel is slightly heavy with the two most intense flavors being a nutty cracked wheat and a mixture of nutmeg and cinnamon.

12OZ Bottle. Slightly hazy and brown with a short dense head. Nice mouthfeel, soft carbonation and slightly creamy. Oatmeal and cinnamon in the aroma, tastes very much like a good brown ale with the addition of the oatmeal. Not getting much raisin though.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Spiegelau tulip.

Pours a very dark amber brown with a 1-2 finger creamy tan head. Excellent lacing.

Smell: Smells a lot like fresh baked oatmeal raisin cookies. Typical brown ale aroma paired with cinnamon and raisins.

Taste: Up front is a blast of what tastes like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Cinnamon and raisins are obvious flavors throughout. There is a bit of hoppy bitterness near the finish to go along with toasted malt. Aftertaste is a nice mixture of cinnamon, hops and malt. Very well-balanced.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. You could knock back a few of these without any trouble.

Overall: This is an excellent twist on the traditional American Brown Ale. This is one of my favorites from Cigar City and Im glad they decided to bottle it. Ill be going back for more assuming they keep bottling it.

Tap at BT.  Pours a clear medium brown with a thinning head.  Aroma is creamy oatmeal cookies, ligth vanilla, oats, dusty chocolate, nuts, toast, cream of wheat, similar vanilla jawbreaker candy.  Flavor is cookie-like, doughy, modest milk chocolate, nuts, toast, toasted oats, raisins, brown toasted malts, earth and chocolate- finish is very dry.

12oz bottle with a nice fizzy head, some nice lacing. Some sweetness in the aroma, cinnamon, vanilla, and the distinct smell of raisins. It literally smells like an Oatmeal Raisin Cookie, its crazy. I could smell this all night long. First sip is sweet, some oatmeal, not as much raisins, very nice. Once again Cigar City does not disappoint.
Bottle. Pours brown with a biege head. Aroma of oatmeal raisin cookie. Flavor of oatmeal raisin cookie. Mouthfeel of beer with oatmeal raisin cookie flavor. This beer lives up to its title.

12 oz bottle purchased in Tampa.   Pours a very dark brown rust color, with a very thick tan head. Aroma was very non-descript initially but as the ale warmed the subtle aromas came through.  Slight oatmeal cinnamon comes through in the nose.  Again as the ale warmed the flavors of fruity date, cinnamon, brown sugar, and definite vanilla bean come through.  the mouthfeel is very soft and lush unlike many other brown ales I have sampled.  Give this one time and be patient.

The aroma is sweet and toasted with a touch of oatmeal and raisin. The appearance is orange brown with a medium head. The taste is like the aroma but very light with oatmeal raisin and water. The palate is a bit thin. Overall kind of interesting but not special.

not quite getting what I was hoping. while it still has an oatmeal raisin flavor, this one bows out with a taste of dates and prunes in the begging while the rest of the beer is flat and has a strange bitterness that doesnt work for this beer. its nothing special but its not terrible.

Shared with Mikkel. A handtapped one-liter bottle with flip-top. The name handwriten on the lable - pretty cool actually. The pour is dark brown eith an impressive huge and fluffy cappochino coloured head. The nose is actually pretty anonymous- mostly with chocolate and some maltes and some strange metallic notes and finaly some sweetness. Its a typical brown ale again with some metallic notes in the taste. The palate is medium with a mild and sweet finish. Thumps up for the bottle.

GABF 2010.  Pours a very dark brown color with a nice frothy tannish head sitting on top of the beer.  The aroma is heavenly and exactly what they were going for.  Smells just like a fresh oatmeal raisin cookie, sweet and sugary, slightly roasty, with lots of raisins.  The flavor is not quite as amazing but still excellent.  Roast, brown sugar, nuts, oatmeal, and a great raisiny dark fruit presence.  Medium-plus bodied and lightly carbonated with a smooth mouthfeel.  Overall, well, people accuse me of overrating Cigar City beers so this high rating doesnt help my cause, but "I like the cut of their jib" as the saying goes.  This beer is very well-executed.

Mini growler via trade with hopscotch - Pours a dark brown color with a 3/4 finger thick light tan head.  Spotty lacing.  Aroma is spice, esters, and light toasted malt.  Flavor is raisin, spice, and toasted malt.  Medium body.  Smooth finish.  Taste like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Well done.  Thanks Eric.

Lucent dark mahagony, thin beige head, medium-full body, medium carbonation.

Aroma: very sweet, oatmeal, raisin, and cinnimon.

Taste: very sweet oatmeal raisin cookie.

My wife took a sip while i was pulling up this page, laughed, and said, "you wont like it." Shes right -i dont like cinnimon. She can have it.
on tap, muddy brown with thin tan foam, aroma of holiday spice, flavors are an oatmeal cookie although a tad thin , didnt have the richness or depth I was hoping for, fnish is smooth

Black beer with a frothy tan head. Some aromas of cinnamon and chocolate detected. As for the taste... color me unimpressed. With such an awesome name I thought this beer would be great, but it was just slightly above average. Tastes of vanilla beans, subtle chocolate, cinnamon, a lot of oatmeal(this was nice), and a tiny bit of raisins. The oatmeal taste was interesting but not amazing. This was a decent enough brown ale.

Sampled at GABF 2010.  Clear brown pour with white head.  Aroma of lots of spices, cinamon, some raisin and a bit of chocolate.  Yup, like an Oatmeal Raisin Cookie.  Flavor is good, again, really similar to an oatmeal raisin cookie. Medium mouthfeel.   Its good, but not totally my style.  Pretty impressive they could nail that flavor profile.

Nice deep reddish-brown colored pour.  Decent tan foamy head.  Aroma is mild but pleasant.  Mostly just some faint roasty notes.  Flavor is more interesting. Some cinnamon, hints of raisin, and a nice light mouthfeel.VERY drinkable.

I would definitely drink this again if given the chance.

Hazy light brown color/ beige head. Nice fresh baked oatmeal raison cinnamon cookie aromas. light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet n spicy cinnamon, raison, brown sugar, cookie dough flavors. great flavors here,  only lacks a rich mouthfeel.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: CCB Mini Growler sent to me by Matt (50belair), many thanks!  Poured a mahogany hue with a small fizzy head and spotty lace, the growler had leaked but the carbonation is just fine. The aroma is much as the name indicates, you get a raisin (and sugar covered plum) fruitiness that reminds me a bit of the Abbey Ales along with a toasted oatmeal cookie vapour. A hint of Cavendish pipe tobacco and alcohol phenols as well. The taste is more towards the roasted kilned malts upfront with a definite fruity supporting cast. Some of that sugary spice and cinnamom bun tones found on the nose along with some of the tobacco character and a touch of butterscotch . Long aftertaste of over-ripened dark fruits. Earthy and twangy with a slight medicinal finish. The mouth feel is smooth and a bit oily, soft finish with a bit of alcohol warming. The body is actually a bit thinner than I would have hoped to better match the flavor profile. Overall it is a neat treat that takes the standard brown ale up a notch (almost more akin to a Strong Ale but anyway)... with a hybrid characteristics that you get with the raisin and plummy tones. That said I am not sure this is something I would really want to drink much of as the light spice does interfere a bit with my overall enjoyment.
Tasty, lighter, yum.  Backend has a bit of that cookie flavor, youll probably like it, the old lady might too.
Nose is iced cookies, cinnamon, raisin, sugar.  Flavor is cinnamon, nutmeg, roast with nice balancing bitterness.

GABF. Clear brown with white head. Lots of oatmeal cinnamon spice, nutmeg, raisins. Literally smells like fresh baked oatmeal cookies. Again, lots of oatmeal cinnamon in taste, remarkably similar to cookies. Light bitter finish, not very heavy. Hell ya.

The second of two CCB brews I sampled at GABF 2010 - nicely dry, which is a great characteristics, because an experiment like this could easily suffer from being too sweet - what we have instead is rich vanilla, dry roasted nuts and oats, snappy cinnamon character - the roastiness of the malt compliments the other ingredients nicely - tasty and original.

Sampled at GABF!  Second pour of the night that showed a nice chestnut colored body and solid 1/4 inch eggshell head that left lacing.  Aroma was filled with brown sugar, cinnamon, oats, and raisin.  Flavor was liquid oatmeal raisin cookie...truly amazing.  Lots of honey baked biscuit, dark fruit, cinnamon, walnut, and vanilla.  Medium mouthfeel.  Really outstanding!

Sampled at GABF on 9/16/2010. This brown ale pours a medium brown color. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity, sweet and bready with a  hint of raisins. A medium bodied brown ale. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are herbal. Bready and sweet, hints of raisins and cinnamon. Good carbonation. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is ful and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Nose is of cinamon, raisin, toasted/roasted nuts as well. Pours dark brown with a nice khaki head with great staying power. Flavor is more raisin, roasted grains, oats, and cinnamon. Drinks nicely, dry finish, good carbonation.

Draft @ Brewery: Pours a dark hazy brown with a nice white head and lacing. The nose fresh and doughy with notes of toffee, raisin, cinnamon and chocolate chops. Full bodied malty flavor with a good blend of the same spices from the nose. Chewy and delicious, just like a fresh oatmeal raisin cookie.
Hazy mahogany with a medium beige head. Aroma had roasted malt, caramel, drying tannins, dark fruits and nuts. Finished dry.

growler courtesy of matboz.  Pours brown with minimal tan head.  Aroma starts off with a hint of caramel then quickly transforms into oatmeal and raisins. The taste is exactly what you would expect. Finishes off with a hint of cinnamon. overall a tasty beer.

Growler shared by jckp64.  Pour is clear enticing looking brown with a hint of red. Small tan head.  Aroma is clean caramel malt with a hint of dried fruit. Aroma belies the flavor which is quite a surprise.  Starts with caramel malt then quickly transitions into oatmeal raisin cookie. Finish has a cinnamon-sugar flavor that is really nice. A very good surprise.  Thanks John!

Tap @ Cigar City...  Poured deep, reddish with an off-white head.  Very fruity, with notes of plum, grape/raisin and even some blueberry.  Oats and malts definitely came trough for that bready sweetness.  The grains also offered a bitter richness, like a Spanish rice.
on draft at the tasting room poured a nice amber color smelled like cake tasted just like oatmeal cookies good stuff

The similarity to oatmeal raisin cookies in both aroma and taste is just scary.  That said, I dont think oatmeal raisin cookie translates very well into beer, (much like Wells Banana Bread is scary similar to Banana Bread, but it kinda sucks as a beer.), but props to CC for nailing the aroma profile.  Medium sweet and malty, it is an experience.
Pretty aptly named, to begin with. Yes, it smells (and tastes)like an oatmeal raisin cookie. Definite raisin aroma, definite spicy note (cinnamon, mostly) and nicely rich bodied. Very enjoyable brew!

Growler thanks to David. Pours a dark brown color with a thick light brown head. Very lively. The aroma is rich spicy malts, cinnamon and ginger. The flavor is quite drinkable; spices try to dominate, ginger, zingy spicy flavors, some chocolates and vanilla. A nice brown ale. It matches the title.

Growler sample from someone at stone sour ale fest 2010, thank you so much.  Dark brown pour, light tan head.  Sweet roasted malt, bread, raisin, cinnamon, spice, slightly nutty, sweetness (toffee?).  MMmm it does taste like oatmeal raisin cookie, nice.

On tap at the brewery.  I joked that this should be called coffee raisin cookie because when it was cold and first poured, I thought coffee was the dominant flavor.  As it warmed up, the oatmeal really took hold.  No shit by the end of the pint it really tasted like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  The pour was a hazy brown and the aroma was toffee and roasted malt.

Growler 32fl.oz.Unclear medium to dark orange amber color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, spicy, wood. berry sour notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100709]

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2011 Draft at Tanks Taproom (Carrollwood, FL) during Beertopia 2010.  Rich brown color with a foamy tan head.  Lots of cinnamon, raisin, and spices in the aroma.  The flavor tasted extactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie, wow!  Very interesting and delicious, although it would be hard to enjoy more than one in a sitting I think, but delicious nonetheless.

Growler. Thanks Hopscoth for providing! Pours hazy deep amber with a medium off white head. The aroma is caramel, light acidic, bit infected like and some spicy fruit. Flavour has some tart acidic disturbing notes along with the caramel, dark fruit and spices. I was the only one at the table that had this experience with the tartness so I mustve been unlucky.

32 fl oz growler. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is slight yeasty, grassy and citrusy. Dark malty, slight herbal to spiced. Cookie and caramelish. Vague fruity note. Slight yeasty touch into a medium dry finish.

cloudy brown, smooth light brown head.
spicy aroma. cookies, spices, strange bitterness.
nice spicy flavor,  quite spicy, also faint orange, dark caramel.

Growler 95cl. Courtesy of Plovmand. Pours a cloudy nutty brown with a beige head. Spicy, herbal aroma - hard to detect exactly what though. Some wood. Medium body, nuts and brown sugar and again a fairly solid spiciness. Dryish finish. A little overcarbonated. A fairly exotic experiment. 090710

Growler. An unclear dark red beer with a tan head. The aroma has notes of spices, malt, caramel, brown sugar, and oatmeal. The flavor is sweet with notes of spices, oatmeal, wood, roasted malt, and brown sugar, leading to a dry spicy finish, where the alcohol leaves a slight bite on the palate. Thanks plovmand for sharing.

Growler. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense brown head. Aroma of raisin, sterin, light roast, spiced. Flavour of chocolate, sweetness, roast, spice, light raisin and some cocoa. Medium bodied. Dry spiced end.

Shared by DosBeerigos from his 32oz growler. The aromas were great. It was just like I expected with sweet aromas of raisins, brown sugar, oatmeal, malts etc. The color was dark brown and no foam collected when poured. The growler might have been in the fridge for a few days so it was a more then a little flat and the carbonation had died, but it was still very tasty.
Draft. Like the vanilla version this version looks just like the original. It feels a tad thicker. The barley and fruit comes through nicely.

Had at 32oz growler from cigar city. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is great with oatmeal, raisin, cinnamon, chocolate, overall excellent. Taste doesnt exactly live up to the look and smell. I feel like the oatmeal raisin overcompensates when it should blend well with the brown ale. Cinnamon, earthy notes also. Palate is light bodied with medium carbonation. A pretty decent beer from cigar city but i felt it could have been better.

32 ounce growler thanks to HOPSHUNTER. Pours with a super thick carbonated head (even after shipping!). Caramel. Sweetness. Brown sugar. And a bit of cookie! These guys are the kings of the brown ale. They take the brown ale recipe and bend it and break it each way that they can.  Another hit from Cigar City.

Poured a very dark amber-brown color with a medium-sized tan head that left some lacing. Sweet aromas of chocolate and brown sugar. Very good flavors of molasses/brown sugar, chocolate and raisins. It really did taste like an oatmeal raising cookie. Very rich and delicious. An excellent beer and one of the best Brown Ales Ive ever had.

A dark reddish copper ale with a thin light moka head. A light sweet chocolate aroma with light vanilla wafting. In mouth, chocolate and raisins, as the name suggests, with smooth woody notes, very nice floral hops in background, all in smoothness, vanilla in finale. On tap at Cigar City, May 22 2010.

Growler shared by DuffmanSW compliments of laroja. Poured a dark brown with tiny beige head. Aroma was dark raisins, cinnamon, cookie dough.
Taste was cinnamon, ginger bread cookie, dark fruits and a tiny bit of bitterness from hops. Overall this stuff rocked.
Growler thanks to laroja...pours dark dark brown with a thin tan head..Smells just like a oatmeal raisin cookie with some cinnamon ..Flavor is has a nice oatmeal cinnamon thing going on..Good beer.

Growler.  Pours a black coffee brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is very much like an oatmeal cookie...cinnamon, raisins, chocolate, caramel and brown sugar.  Flavor is more bitter and less sweet than expected, which is a good thing.  Cinnamon, chocolate, a very smooth, earthy bitterness and a slight alcohol presence.  Medium to full bodied with light carbonation.

Tap at Rattle N Hum.  Yup it tastes exactly like an oatmeal raison cookie.  Brown sugar, raisins and sweet toasted oats.  Great concept executed to perfection.  Really lovely.  There is a bit of cinnamon on the back of the palate.  Im really shocked and pleased that this turned out this well.  Really great stuff.

On draft at Cigar City. Pours dark brown with a medium head, lasting carbonation. Aroma is tons of raisins, dark fruits, and chocolate. Flavor is raisins, burnt wood, and oats. Medium bodied, slight warmth. Really good...

Growler from the brewery. Pours dark brown with reddish highlights and a tan head. Smells like an oatmeal raisin cookie - raisins and cinnamon. Flavor of roasted malts, cinnamon and raisins. Medium body with moderate carbonation. A good, easy drinking beer.

On tap at Cigar City Brewery, sweet malty aroma pours deep mahogany.  Taste focused around  a roasted malt bitterness, medium sweetness, low hop bitterness, overall a bit disappointing when compared to the other Cigar City brews.

Aroma was a little on the soft side,this came from a growler that was about a week old,I was able to fish out some good hints of brown sugary caramel,with a wisp of Molassas and anise. flavor was also hard to hold on to,choclate,caramel, a little finish of what could be cinnimon and raisin,a touch of sweetness in the beginning,great satisfying initail flavor,but it really faded fast. I suspect it would hold on longer if it were fresher
Draft. Brown pour with some head. Well, this literally tastes like you are drinking oatmeal raisin cookies, Im not sure what else to write. Nice flavor, not overly sweet.

Pours a translucent brown with dark amber-ish highlights from the 32oz. growler courtesy of Mike (thejon375): Unfortunately, the growler was aged a while so the taste and nose are both pretty thin. But I can still tell CCB pulled it off. Nose of whole coffee beans, spiced licorice, nicely laced dark tropical fruit, and of course, oats, raisins, and cookie dough. Flavors are similar with added sweet malts. Drinkability: True to the real thing. Pairing: Spiced apple pie. Rebuy: Yes. #382 on 07042010, DG.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Draft at rnh for cigar city event. The beer poured a dark brown body with a ruby tint and a small tan head. Aroma of oatmeal cookie and caramel. Medium/thin mouthfeel with great flavours of oatmeal cookie, raisin, dark fruits, cinnamon, sugar, incredible - the beer of the night for me personally, and hands down the best brown ale Ive ever tried. Hats off to cigar city.

draft, brewery- literally, an oatmeal cookie- cinnamon for sure- easy to see how they did that- but how the hell did they get the raisin in the finish- still boggling my mind- only thing- too thin- wanted something thicker, chewier.

Tap at CCB courtesy of sebletitje.  Best beer in the tasting room!  Close your eyes, and you really are eating oatmeal raisin cookies - its amazing.  Shockingly good, THE surprise of the night.  Worth seeking out.

This beer is pretty much pure joy and happiness in liquid form.  The pour looks like every other Maduro Brown, brown with a modest light tan head.  The mouthfeel is like every other Maduro Brown, not thin by any standard but not exactly swarming with creaminess.  This beer sets itself apart by smelling eggs-act-lee like a fucking oatmeal raisin cookie.  I mean, holy hell.  This is one of those beers that smells so good you want to keep all of it in your glass to savor the aroma.  It is that wonderful.  The taste is really good and hits exactly what it wants to.  That taste is pretty darn good, but its the knockout aroma that makes this a must grab any time it hits the CCB draft list.

Tap @ Rattle n Hum, NYC (from notes).  Pours a murky brown with a wispy off-white head.  Aroma is that of a traditional brown ale, though I detected some dark fruit and an ever-so-slight hint of cinnamon.  Taste is pretty standard brown ale, but then it explodes into a cinnamon/raisin/oat characteristic....and damned if it didnt taste exactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  It would have been so easy for this beer to be out of balance, too sweet, or too weak, but it was a home run.  Amazing, amazing beer.

Had at the Hunahpu release party as a part of RBWG 2010 (I think on cask?).  A creamy brown pour without much head.  The aroma is mild spices and some dark fruits, but mostly brown ale.  The flavor and feel were a bit thinner than I was hoping, and I cant say I would have guessed oatmeal raisin cookie without being told, but the resemblance is definitely there.
(Cask)  Pours a murky brown body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of raisins, oatmeal, and grain.  Flavor of raisins, grass, vanilla, caramel, and oatmeal with a dry, bitter finish.

Cask.  Murky dark brown body topped by small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, raisin, caramel, some cookie dough.  Taste is moderately sweet, oatmeal raisin cookie (really!), light earthy.  Medium body.

Cask at Hunahpu release. Wow, this beer tasted pretty much as advertised--an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Crazy.  An interesting beer, and good if you like oatmeal raisin cookies. If you dont, probably not going to be your favorite beer. Not my favorite kind of cookie, so just an average beer for me. Still, I admire their ability to recreate the flavor in liquid form!

on tap @RNH for the CCB event.   This and the straight up Hunhnapu (sp?) were my favorites of the event.  Dark brown in color with ruby highlights, and a small but lasting tan head.  Aroma of oatmeal cookie spices and caramel - strong but very appropriate considering the name.  Taste was alot of sweet malt - oatmeal, dark fruit (raisins) and spices.  Medium bodied, tasted just as intended - CCB really nailed this beer.   The only disappointment was that I had almost half of this beer left  in my tulip and took a restroom break and a waittress apparently thought I was done with it and took it away.   That was f**ked up!

cask at hunahpus release party.  first pour after tap was hammered in, poured by wayne himself!  light aroma of fig/prune.  color is ultra hazy mud.  copious O2 foam, flavor is biting mild ale like caramel up front followed by fleeting oat sweetness later.  fat mouthfeel despite lack of carb.  by end of pint aroma evolves to dry kibble.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Pours a deep dark chocolate brown color with lighter chestnut brown edges when held to a light source and a half finger light yellowish beige color head that quickly fades into a thin lasting ring . Sporadic spots of lacing.

Slightly spicy dark fruit aroma with hints of dark fruit, roasted caramel malt, toffee and subtle spice.  Hints of toffee, subtle coffee, caramel and chocolate malt .  Slight alcohol.

Slightly chewy medium body with hints of caramel malt, toffee, slight dark fruit and alcohol.
pretty mild brown color.  great sweeter aroma.  mildish flavor but good.  great feel and goes down great!  good beer

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2010 sample from the pitcher @ GABF on 9/18/10.  brown pour with a small tan head.  oatmeal raisin cookie aromas - I could smell this all day!  carbonated medium body with more oatmeal, sugar, dark malts.  sweet oatmeal raisin cookie aftertaste.  wonderful and unique!

tasting on 3/6/10... brown pour with a little tan head... smells just like an oatmeal raisin cookie... lots of sugar, oatmeal, cookie dough along with the dark malts in the base beer... liquid goodness.... really unique and tasty beer.

Tap at RattlenHum. Not gonna lie, this was my favorite beer at the CCB event and probably my favorite Ive had from them. It just nails the cookie profile so perfectly, while still retaining some beeriness. And, lo-and-behold, it is actually kind of sessionable. I could drink this all day. Warning: dont say you like this better than BA Hunahpus or youll get chastised.

Draft at Rattle N Hum during the CCB event. This is basically a liquid dessert. Aroma of sugar, oats, raisin, cinnamon and nutmeg. The flavor is sweet and almost sugary as the rasins and spices combine before melding in with the oats. The body was a little thin and if it was thick and chewy I would never eat an actual desert ever again but simply put a keg of this on in my basement and hit it up after every meal, even breakfast.

Tap at Rattle n Hum.  Nose is oatmeal raisin cookie seriously.  Flavor is watery rich brown ale with huge oatmeal raisin notes. Lots of sweetness and some decent malts. This is as stated. As opposed To brooklyn cookie jar.

Tap at Rattle n Hum: Deep rusty copper with a fading head. Great aroma- like an oatmeal raisin cookie (surprise!). Has lots of brown sugar, oats and raisins. The palate is surprisingly lacking, considering Id bet they used oats in the mash which would provide a thicker mouthfeel. The flavor is still great. Cinnamon, oatmeal, brown sugar, raisins and a clean dry finish. A unique and balanced ale that captures the experience of an oatmeal raisin cookie. Id only wish it was fuller on the palate.

Dark brown, thin white head.  Aromas are full on oatmeal cookie dough and cinnamon raisin throughout.  Brown sugared raisins, cinnamon, and nutmeg combine to bring a liquid oatmeal cookie together in the glass.  Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, spiced cookie finish.  Loved the creativity

Let me just start by saying this beer is severely under rated.  Pours a mahogany body with a white head.  Cherry raisin cookie notes, oatmeal and raisin notes amongst a lightly chocolate body with lush dark raisins and a full bodied finish.  Fantastic.

On tap at Rattle n Hum.  Wow!  What a beer!  This beer really delivers what its supposed to... Raisin Cookie to a tee.   Brown sugar, rich honey gram whole oats, and raisins.   No, Im not reading the back of a cereal box... this stuff is awesome!  So many times I try to pick up flavors of the brewers description.. not this sucker.   Perfectly executed + originality points.  4.45

Tap @ Rattle n Hum.  Poured a clear deep chestnut color.  The aroma was of cinnamon and raisins.  It really did smell like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Yummy.  The flavor continued the oatmeal and raisin them with some caramel and coffee notes as well.  Light-medium bodied.

On tap at a location that will remain nameless.  Poured a clera dark brown with a smallish beige head.  Aroma was awesome, just like oatmeal rasin cookies. Taste is also just like oatmeal rasin cookies, as hard is that is to say.   The use of spice and dark fruit really peg the oatmeal rasin flavor perfectly.  The mouth was smooth and medium bodied.  Overall, an awesome brew.  Hard to rate this very low, though it does not taste like a beer.  Not sure if that matters...

Tap @ RnH - Dar kred/brown pour arouma is amazing cookie, raisin. Some prune and sweet dark malts backed by fresh bitter hops. Biscuit and some chocolate and smokey roast. some spice. amazing that they pulled off this genuine cookie beer.
Draft at RnH. Pours brown with a beige head. Sweet fresh baked cookie aroma, with raisins and oatmeal. Literally tastes like liquid cookie. Very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 On tap at Cigar City takes NYC event at Rattle N Hum Yummy,though on the sweet(sugar and lots of malt) and spicy side: cinammon, this kicked early.
The chocolate malt, raisiny taste was in the background. Dark with a whisp of head, appropriately carbonated. Cute, but I could not drink pints of this.

On tap at Rattle N Hum for their Cigar City event.  Pours a clear ruby brown with a thin white head.  Sweet cinnamon, spice, oatmeal.  Throughout the course of the evening I must have heard 10-15 people say what I said uninfluenced after the first time I tried it:  Smells and tastes like what I wanted the Cookie Jar Porter to taste like.  Like a liquefied beer cookie.  Sweet malty, more cookie flavor.  Phenomenally good flavor.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Deep amber pour. The aroma comes out of a cookbook: cinnamon, raisins, brown sugar... you get the idea. There is a bit of an excess of cinnamon, as though were making spicy oatmeal raisin cookies. A really awesome smell all together. The flavor is deconstructed oatmeal raisin cookie: margarine, brown sugar, oak, and raisins. The body is a bit flat. Slight warming cinnamon finish. The flavors are a bit more earthy than the aroma. I want to smell this some more. Not necessarily my favorite Cigar City beer but possibly the most memorable.

The aroma is oatmeal, brown sugar, fruit, nuts.  Like a cookie.  The appearance is a clear dark red, white head.  The flavor is awesome, oatmeal, brown sugar, raisins, fruity, excellent.  The finish is light hop bittering, sweet, oatmeal.  Really like an Oatmeal raisin cookie.  CCB really nailed this one.

on draft at cigar city brewing.  pours a dark brown.  oats and nuts on the nose along with some cinnamon and spices.  Good dark malt base.  it tastes literally just like a liquid oatmeal raisin cookie and a good one at that, which isnt even something id think id like that much, but that just shows what i know.  this is a really delicious beer.

Tap. Heavy aromas of bread and roasted oatmeal for the malt, light herbs for the hops, with loads of vanilla, ginger, cinnamon and raisin in the background. Head is large, creamy, light brown with some lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy dark copper/brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is on the heavier side of medium, slick with a lively carbonation. This smells and tastes exactly like oatmeal raisin cookies. I wouldnt have thought id like it.

After trying to get this beer for a long, long time, juiceisloose hooked me up big time. This beer is great. Pours a blackish-purple-brown that just kind of looks like a raisin. Aroma is fantastic; oats, spice, brown sugar, toasted nuts, and a hint of chocolate. Light sweetness in flavor, with a hint of coffee and toffee. A tad too thin on the palate, but dammit this beer was awesome and Im very thankful I had the chance to try this. Thanks Justin!
Oh my god...this is the greatest stuff ever made. Buddy of mine told me to try some in a blind tasting...Instantly knew what is was, Id take this over gmas oatmeal raisin cookies any day.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, dark brown body with some golden-orange edges and topped with a layer of thin, off-white froth.

Smell: Well, Ill be a monkeys uncle! It does indeed smell like oatmeal raisin cookies.

Taste: Sweet-tasting chocolate morsels stirred up with dark brown sugar, toasted rolled oats, a liberal dose of spices, hints of roast, and a box raisins with that bonnet-wearing chick on the front. Does a fantastic job of mimicking the flavor of oatmeal raisin cookies.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A very satisfying, enjoyable beer; another in a series of hits from Cigar City. This is one for the books!

32oz Growler.  Dark brown color.  Aroma of sugar, raisin, dough.  Flavor of an Fn Oatmeal Cinnamon Raisin Cookie!!!  FUCK!  This is the most unique and clever beer Ive ever had.  And I could completely drink this all day every day...

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Growler from my buddy Ned... Pours a medium cola brown with a thin light tan head that quickly dissipates... Aroma of standard maduro but flavor has some added sweetness along with a light spice to it. Dark fruit, raisins, and a little cocoa nib and nuttiness. I do get a little oatmeal cookie in there but somewhat of a stretch.  Medium carbonation with thin to medium body.

Appearance: clear dark brown, wispy beige head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet caramel and chocolate aroma, rich dark fruits

Pours a nice amber color with a tan head.  Aroma is cinnamon, oatmeal, biscuit, and raisin.  It smells exactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Flavor is oatmeal, raisin, cinnamon and a bitter spicy finish.

Growler Wilkes brought up from Tampa.  From the brewery.  Reddish brown pour with a finger tan head and a light sheet of stick.  Yep - oatmeal, raisin and cookie aroma.  Brown sugar, dough, nuts and cinnamon in the flavor.  Light bitter finish.  Little sweet for my tastes, but interesting nonetheless.

This smells exactly like an oatmeal raisin cookie. The smell is amazingly accurate. The flavor is a bit of a let down. The base beer is a little thin and the spice comes across a little too much in the flavor, but wow what a great smelling beer.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Growler from CCB. Pours a deep, clear ruby with a thick yellow head that has awesome retention and lacing. Aroma is cherry Dr. Pepper, some brown sugar oatmeal. Cant get raisins out of it. Taste is very light-bodied, easy to drink. Some black cherry soda. Meh. 12/27/2009 6/5/6/3/10=3.0 355mL. Pours a clear ruby, deeper brown with a large, thick, sheen tan head with good retention and good lace. Aroma is still odd with cookie and
minerals and slight off-character. Taste is pretty much all oatmeal cookie with heavy minerals. Spot on for the gimmick. Palate is relatively poor: thin, suddy, watery. 12/29/2010 6/4/7/3/13=3.3

Ah my favorite cookie transformed into liquid form. Damn this is a good beer. Pours a nice dark reddish brown. Smells of wonderful spices and raisins. Tastes just like its cookie counterpart cinnamon, raisins, bits of oat, brown sugar.
Holy liquid cookie batman!!! Aroma has the oatmeal, spice and raisin. Floral hops are nice. Flavor is sweet and tastes so much like a cookie. Insane. Cinnamon, raisin, oats, brown sugar...hell yes!

Draft sample at Cigar City. Poured a clear brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted oatmeal, sweet spice and small coffee aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Solid roasted oatmeal cookie sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. Standout complex brew.
From a really cool looking growler shared by  JCB.  What can I say that hasnt been said, it smells and tastes like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  A great concept beer.
Growler. This seriously smells like a cinnamon oatmeal cookie! Its nice but the flavor profile is not my preference.
1QT growlerpours a tan head that laces with brown color.  Aroma is dark malt/oats-molasses/ caramel, raisins. Taste is dark malt/oats-molasses/ caramel, raisins,spice.

32 oz mini-growler.  Clear brown with a passing beige head.  Nose is cinnamon, raisin, molasses and oats.  Medium body with a crisp tang.  Taste is cocoa, sour raisin, cinnamon and brown sugar trailing off with tobacco and tar.  Long dry finish with lingering oatmeal cookie.  Despite its novelty a tasty, well-wrought concoction.

Thanks JCB. Pours a reddish copper brown with a one finger frothy light tan head. The nose is spot on, as is the flavor it turns out. Sweet cookie aroma, cinnamon and other sweet spices, raisins for sure, mild notes of toasted grain. Flavor is sweet and malty, mild spice and leafy hop character, cinnamon, bready. Light carbonation on the palate. Very interesting .
Draft at the brewery, and growler.  Smells and tastes exactly as advertised.  Cinnamon, raisin and cookies.  Light to medium bodied, and doesnt take away from the base beer.  A solid treat.

Growler from the brewery. Pours a cloudy and dark mahogany brown color topped by a good sized foamy, off white head. Minimal spots of lacing are left behind. The aroma is dead on for an oatmeal raisin cookie with notes of raisins, cinnamon, and toasted cookie to go along with the cocoa and caramel malt base. The flavor follows suit with the cocoa and caramel malts up front to go with some vanilla, cinnamon, and raisins. Medium bodied and very smooth with an almost cookie like mouthfeel from the oatmeal. This is just a really nice and tasty brown ale. Really good stuff.

Growler from RomaniIteDominum on BA - thanks, Stephen! Stubby little guy, compact like a lunchbox, and you know Mom packed them cookies. And CCB is not messing around with the cookies, hitting it perfectly with brown sugar and cinnamon. Nice base beer, and the oatmeal gives it a dry doughy finish. In a certain sense it reminded me of a variation on Anchors OSA, but it really held its own character well. They hit the mark, in a much more satisfying way than, say, STs Creme Brulee. Somebody give me Shorts Uber Goober now.

Lil growler, thanks to Jason.  Pours reddish brown with small off-white head.  Pretty much all of us who tasted it stated the obvious after the first sip: "Tastes like an oatmeal raisin cookie."  Surprisingly, this is a good thing -- nice cinnamon, raisin, oatmeal, doughy goodness, some vanilla and brown sugar.  Doesnt end up being overly sweet or cloying.  Light palate, but not flat or boring. Very drinkable and quite enjoyable.  Not just a novelty.

Thanks to JCB for sharing this!  Brown pour with a beige head.  Aroma of raisin, chocolate and light spice.  Flavor is really nice, and the name does not lie, it tastes like a oatmeal raisin cookie.  Unique and quite complex

Growler from the brewery.  Looks like Maduro and all the other treatments, dark brown, thin whispy head.  The aroma smells mild but nice, roasted malt, a little chocolate and a dash of raisin although its so subtle I wonder if I picked that up because I was looking for it.  Theres no mistaking the oatmeal cookies in the flavor though.  Cookies mix with toasty caramel, bakers chocolate, nuts, and some hops round it out.  This really does taste like Maduro with oatmeal cookies so I think Cigar City did what they intended with this one.  These Maduro treatments are fun and theyre always good but I think Maduro is best on its own.

Growler October 09 O-Town Throwdown! Mostly clear, burnt orange ale with a small, fat-bubbled head. The aroma is straight out of Grandmas kitchen  oatmeal cookies with brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon; hell, even raisins. Light-bodied with lively carbonation. Balanced flavor, but watery. Some nice spice, but more thin than original Maduro. Crisp, lightly bitter finish. Growler courtesy of cmillward!

Growler courtesy cmillward.  Pours a medium brown color, with a small off white head.  Smells of oats, nuts, and dark sweet malts.  Definitely has that cookie presence in there.  Definitely has that oatmeal raisin cookie effect going as well as you get the little fruitiness to go along with that nutty oat character.  they hit it on the head if they were going for that, which Im sure they were given the name of the brew.  Another nice brew from these guys.
The straightforward oatmeal raisin cookie aroma is met with subtle roasted flavors, oats, malts and company. Not as sweet as one might expect.  A pleasing spin on the Maduro.

Seriously! This is a cookie in a bottle. Brown color with plum highlights. Aroma has oats, molasses, raisins, sugar, caramel and cookies. Flavor is like cake, gentle spice, raisins, oats, cream, nuts and toffee. I think CC nailed this one, tastes like an oatmeal raisin cookie.

growler thanks to Todd.  Caramel on the nose with hints of ginger and raisons.  As it warms more of the "cookie" aromas seem to appear, very nice.  Pours brown with a thin off white head.  Ginger and allspice, caramel and raisons, toasted oats, brown sugar, man it really tastes like an oatmeal cookie, especially as it warms slightly.  Although it seems to be a little thin on the palate.  But overall and excellent treatment to a great beer!

Growler, courtesy cmillward.  Pours a hazy, dark, caramel-chestnut brown hue that glows slightly reddish in the light.  A small, frothy, off-white head settles in to a bubbly film, leaving behind minimal, scattered spots of lacing.  They nailed the aroma, as it really does smell very much like an oatmeal raisin cookie.  Notes of toasted cookie dough join the base caramel and cocoa, while oats smooth things out even further and hints of raisin lend a fruity earthiness. Flavors show the same base elements, but seem far less defined, a bit more muddled.  Caramel and vanilla emerge, while hints of soft cocoa roast balance things out a little.  Medium bodied and smooth, it drinks so easily.  Good stuff.

Tasted at Otown Throwdown. Hazy brown pour. Huge oatmeal, raisin and sweet cookie malt aroma. Aroma lives up to the name. Chocolate roasted grain, raisin in the taste. Taste cant keep up with the aroma, good brew nonetheless.

dark amber with an off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, nuts, oats, toast, roast, and espresso.  Taste of caramel malts, nuts, raisins, oatmeal, and roast, with a dry finish.

Draft.  Poured a dark brown amber with a thin beige head.  Nose is oatmeal cookies.  I agree with TampaBrew that the flavor is even more spot on oatmeal cookie than the aroma.  Very interseting, I actually loved this Maduro treatment.  On a cool fall night I could drink a gallon of this.  Great job Doug!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 On tap at the Brass Tap. Pours a opaque brown. Nose is an Oatmeal cookie! Cinnamon, raisin, plum, roasted grains, toasty malt, oatmeal. Flavor is even more cookie-ish. Perfect balance of cinnamon and spices with sweet raisins and oats. This is one of my favorite treatments of Maduro. Made me want to start a fire, sit back with an actually oatmeal cookie and enjoy the chilly Florida 70 degree winter nights. I loved this!

On tap at Brass Tap.  Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is oatmeal, raisin, sugar, cinnamon, brown sugar, tobacco, and vanilla.  FL is similar with lots of sugar, vanilla, and tobacco.  Excellent Brown ale and great sweetness.  Medium bodied and excellent for Maduro- the cookie part of it cushions the tobacco-esque bitterness of the Maduro.  A perfect starter beer.

On tap at Brass Tap (Tampa, FL). Pours a amber cola brown with one finger off-white head with good retention. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of nutmeg, cinnamon, caramel, vanilla, fresh raisins --just like an oatmeal cookie. Flavor is sweet and malty as well with similar notes of vanilla, raisins, brown sugar, cinnamon, malty sweetness. Generally medium body with a sweet, malty lightly spicy finish. Very tasty -- if you like oatmeal cookies.

Big cheers to Doug for putting this one together for the brass tap event. 

A: Pours an amberish brown, more red than brown which is somewhat suprising as regular maduro pours pretty brown. Nice tall head that shows good retention and leggy lace. 

S: Wonder aromas of dark fruit, chocolate, and cinnamon. 

T: The nice malty nutty maduro is there right from the start. Real vanilla and cinnamon push through in the middle. A raisin sweetness can be picked up in the finish along with more cinnamon. 

M: On the lighter side of medium. Smooth drinking beer. 

D: Not the most drinkable due to the sweetness. One tasty treat though that I hope to see again.

On tap at The Brass Tap. It pours amber with tan head and lasting tan spider web lacing. The aroma carries some malts, a bit of roast, vanilla spice, cinnamon, raisin and a touch of nuttiness. The taste starts neutral for a moment or two and then moves into malts and nuttiness. By midway raisins, vanilla and some spicy cinnamon surface and push this toward the finish with the vanilla and cinnamon spice growing right into the after taste.
